hero_dishes.name: Sarmale
hero_dishes.description: Cabbage rolls stuffed with minced meat (pork and beef), rice, and aromatic spices, slow-cooked until tender
hero_dishes.origin_story: A cornerstone of Romanian cuisine with roots in the Ottoman Empire. Each family has their secret spice blend passed down through generations. Making sarmale is a communal activity during holidays.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Caru' cu Bere (iconic 1879 brewery-restaurant), Vatra, Hanu' lui Manuc. Always served with mÄƒmÄƒligÄƒ (polenta) and sour cream.

hero_dishes.name: Mici/Mititei
hero_dishes.description: Grilled skinless sausages made from minced meat (beef, pork, lamb) with garlic, black pepper, and secret spice blends
hero_dishes.origin_story: Legend says mici were invented by accident at a Bucharest inn when they ran out of sausage casings. The name means 'little ones.' Now they're essential at any Romanian gathering.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Zexe (with live piano music), Obor Market (street food style), beer gardens throughout Bucharest. Must be served with mustard and fresh bread.

hero_dishes.origin_story: The ultimate Romanian hangover cure and comfort food. The sour taste comes from borÈ™ (fermented wheat bran) or vinegar. Making it properly takes hours of preparation.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: CiorbÄƒrie ('the soup factory' - specializes in various ciorbÄƒ), Locanta Jaristea, traditional restaurants. Often eaten as a meal, not just starter.

hero_dishes.name: PapanaÈ™i
hero_dishes.description: Romanian-style doughnuts made with sweet cheese, served with sour cream and berry jam (typically sour cherry or blueberry)
hero_dishes.origin_story: A beloved dessert dating back centuries, with regional variations across Romania. The name may derive from 'papa' (food for priests). The combination of sweet, sour, and creamy is quintessentially Romanian.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Vatra (known for sweet dishes), Caru' cu Bere, Zexe. Best served warm with generous toppings.

signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Romanian wines are underrated treasures. Locals pair red wines with mici and sarmale, white wines with ciorbÄƒ. Wine culture is experiencing a renaissance.
